NOTES

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In 1998, the Government asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and World Bank to 
help  carry  out  a  comprehensive  study  of  the  Philippine  education  sector.1  This  study 
subsequently  became  a  major  input  into  the  work  of  the  Presidential  Commission  on 
Educational Reform (PCER), which conducted its deliberations from 1998 to 2000. Following 
the release of PCER’s report,2 the Government requested financial and technical assistance 
(TA) from ADB to support the implementation of PCER’s major recommendations. A project 
preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) for the Higher Education Development Project (HEDP) 
was approved on 12 October 2000, in the amount of $998,000.3 HEDP is now in the final stages 
of preparation and is scheduled for approval in 2003.  
 
2.  HEDP  will  implement  key  recommendations  contained  in  the  PCER  report  and 
Philippines  Education  Sector  Study,  as  well  as  the  Government’s  Medium-Term  Philippine 
Development  Plan,  2001–2004  and  the  Medium-Term  Higher  Education  Development  and 
Investment Plan, 2001–2004. A common recommendation is to rationalize the allocation of 
scarce resources to maximize public funding for basic education. The rapidly expanding public 
higher education system is exerting considerable pressure upon the education budget. To limit 
this pressure, fundamental reform of the higher education system in finance and governance is 
necessary.  
 
3.  One of the PPTA findings was that the capacity of the Commission on Higher Education 
(CHED) to spearhead a reform agenda is limited. The Government therefore requested advisory 
technical assistance (ADTA) from ADB to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of CHED and 
prepare it to implement HEDP. A fact-finding mission for the ADTA was carried out in February 
2002, along with a loan fact-finding mission for HEDP.4 The Government has concurred with the 
TA framework (Appendix 1), implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and 
terms of reference.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  The formal education cycle comprises only 10 years of basic education (elementary plus 
secondary), postbasic education offering nondegree courses of varying lengths, and 4 years of 
higher education covering degree-granting courses. Almost all elementary education (grades 1–
6) is publicly provided, but 25% of secondary (grades 7–10) and 75% of higher education 
enrollment is in the private sector. Participation rates and gender equity at all levels are among 
the highest in the region, and the workforce is relatively well educated. Nevertheless, the public 
perception is that the quality of education at all levels has declined significantly in recent 
decades. In higher education, this view is supported by the 1999 and 2000 Asiaweek surveys of 
the  80  top-ranking  regional  universities,  where  the  premier  university  (University  of  the 
Philippines) ranked only 44th. As recently as the 1970s, the Philippines was seen as one of the 
region’s leading education centers. Average passing rates in the annual professional licensure

examinations are also low, averaging only around 45%. The pervasive low quality of higher

5.  Reform  is  urgent  to  redress  the  low  quality  and  pervasive  inefficiency  in  higher 
education. First, the skills and competencies of graduates must be raised to prepare them for 
productive work in the domestic and global labor markets, and thereby enhance Philippine 
competitiveness. Second, reform is necessary to enable the system to accommodate an ever-
increasing number of high school graduates, and to offer children an incentive to complete basic 
education and provide them with a pathway out of poverty and into the labor market. To ensure 
that  the  poor  are  provided  with  improved  employment  opportunities,  they  should  acquire 
qualifications  in  higher  education.  This  is  particularly  important  in  the  Philippines,  where 
participation rates in basic education are already high, and high school graduates are on 
average only 16 years old. An efficient and effective higher education system is vital to ensure 
these opportunities. Finally, in view of the budgetary situation, tertiary institutions must be 
weaned gradually from public funding and their resource utilization improved so that public 
funds can be released for lower levels of the system.  
  
6.  HEDP responds to these imperatives by supporting reforms that will rationalize and 
strengthen the higher education system while improving the poor’s access to it. In the long term, 
improved efficiency and effectiveness in the use of public resources will help ensure that pro-
poor funding for basic education will be maintained or increased. HEDP has three general 
objectives:  (i)  improved  efficiency,  to  rationalize  the  system  of  education  financing  and 
governance to improve resource utilization and help stem the uncontrolled growth in the number 
of  higher  education  institutions  and  programs;  (ii)  enhanced  quality,  to  improve  quality 
assurance and the quality of educational achievements and outcomes; and (iii) greater equity, to 
enhance access to higher levels of the education system among lower-income groups. 
 
7.  Higher education has always been led by the private sector. Over recent decades, 
however, public provision and financing have expanded rapidly with the establishment by the 
legislature of many, generally low-quality, public higher education institutions (HEIs). As a result, 
the private share of student enrollment has decreased significantly, from 90% in the early 1980s 
to less than 74% in SY2000/01. At the same time, the higher education system as a whole has 
continued to expand. In the last 7 years alone, the overall student population increased by 35%. 
Public sector enrollments, however, increased by a massive 66%, compared with 27% in the 
private sector.  
 
8.  This rapid expansion of publicly funded higher education has required large increases in 
public funding for higher education. Between 1988 and 1999, the higher education budget 
expanded by 23% while the basic education budget increased by only 5%. To reverse the 
resultant trend of a diminishing basic education budget share, the Government has for the last 
few years pegged the higher education budget at around 15% of the total education budget. 
However, public higher education spending, as a result, has become increasingly inadequate to 
support the needs of the continually expanding public sector. Complementary reform strategies 
are urgently needed to increase cost recovery in public sector institutions, improve efficiency in 
public spending, and contain or rationalize the growth of the public sector. In the absence of 
these reforms, further deterioration in the quality and efficiency of public higher education can 
be expected. At the same time, the viability of private sector institutions will continue to diminish 
as students are attracted by the low fees of publicly-funded institutions. 
 
9.  Responsibility for education is split among three agencies. The oldest is the Department 
of Education, which was formerly responsible for the whole sector. The department’s focus

3 
changed to basic education in 1994, when two new agencies were created to cover the other 
subsectors of education: CHED, to oversee higher education; and the Technical Education and 
Skills Development Authority, to handle technical and vocational education and training. CHED 
is  legally  mandated  to  develop  the  quality  and  relevance  of  higher  education  through  the 
development  of  sound  policies  and  plans  to  promote  higher  education,  strategic  resource 
allocation,  standard  setting  and  quality  assurance,  and  establishment  of  an  appropriate 
regulatory environment for the private sector. In practice, CHED has focused mainly upon the 
minutiae of regulation.  
 
10.  To  enable  CHED  to  champion  and  lead  the  reform  process  and  implement  HEDP 
successfully, the agency must be strengthened. One of the most critical reforms is the move to 
a new higher education funding system that will allow the systematic allocation of funds to public 
HEIs in accordance with national priorities. Stronger systems for quality assurance are another 
top priority. To institute these changes and help CHED achieve strong leadership of the sector, 
a comprehensive process of organizational development and capacity building is planned. 
 
III.  THE  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
11.  The purpose of the TA is to enhance CHED’s capacity to implement the recommended 
reforms  through  a  comprehensive  process  of  organizational  development  aimed  at 
strengthening CHED’s role in policy development and planning, resource allocation, and quality 
assurance  in  the  higher  education  system.  The  strategies  to  be  followed  will  include 
restructuring of CHED, improvement of operating systems, developing more effective strategies 
to deal with clients and other agencies, and targeting human resource development (HRD). The 
outputs expected are (i) a set of performance standards and monitoring mechanisms for CHED, 
covering the central and regional offices; (ii) a more effective and efficient organization structure 
to allow the absorption of new responsibilities; (iii) a rationalized staffing pattern with more 
professional staff positions and an early retirement program for implementation under HEDP; 
(iv) new manuals of procedures decentralizing authority to lower levels in the system; (v) a 5-
year HRD program; (vi) increased staff capacity in areas critical to the success of the reforms; 
and (vii) more effective advocacy for reform. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  To ensure an effective program of organizational development and capacity building, an 
organizational analysis of CHED will be carried out. The first exercise will be a performance 
analysis to (i) establish CHED’s performance standards in line with CHED’s core functions, and 
(ii) examine CHED’s performance record to establish CHED’s current performance against 
these standards. With regard to new functions, the exercise will help establish performance 
measures and norms and allow the identification of specific gaps between current performance 
standards and actual performance. The second step will be a diagnostic analysis to identify 
the reasons for the performance gaps. The performance and diagnostic analyses will be carried 
out as group exercises with all CHED commissioners and top management to ensure that 
common understandings and agreements are reached. Some assistance will be provided by 
ADB staff.6 
                                                 
6  The  concepts  of  performance  and  diagnostic  analysis  have  been  referenced  from  the  draft  guidelines  on 
organizational development being developed by the Governance and Regional Cooperation Division.

4 
13.  The  major  factors  contributing  to  performance  that  will  be  examined  during  the 
diagnostic  analysis  are  (i)  resources  (staff,  skills,  budget,  technology,  equipment);  (ii) 
management infrastructure (strategies, policies, structure, and systems and processes); and (iii) 
vision, leadership, and values. The diagnostic analysis will be complementary to and informed 
by the initial institutional assessment carried out under the PPTA.7 This assessment does not 
include a specific performance analysis but thoroughly analyzes factors (i) and (ii). 
 
14.  Recommendations for specific programs of action will flow from the diagnostic analysis, 
and  from  the  initial  institutional  assessment  completed  under  the  PPTA.  Expected  major 
activities are (i) reorganization of CHED’s central office, including the establishment of a rules-
based financing unit, strengthened management of the higher education development fund, and 
new  units  for  liaison  with  Congress  and  the  universities;  (ii)  development  of  a  normative 
financing formula; (iii) reorganization of CHED regional offices to strengthen technical expertise 
and prepare for decentralization; (iv) strengthening of planning capacities in central and regional 
offices; (v) development of a new staffing structure, including the design of an early retirement 
program and the cost implications; (vi) development of a costed, 5-year HRD plan capturing 
CHED’s new roles; and (vii) implementation of a targeted training program, including training 
programs designed by the consultants, and short courses provided by reputable Philippine 
training institutions in strategic planning, management information systems, quality assurance 
and its relationship to planning, project planning, and management.8 For courses costing less 
than $15,000, the institutions will be contracted directly by CHED, and the funds for payment 
disbursed  to  CHED  through  the  Advance  Payment  Facility.  A  detailed  training  program, 
including the names of the institutions, courses, and details of the participants, including their 
current or proposed job duties, must be submitted to ADB for approval before implementation. 
 
15.  Selected, structured study tours will expose CHED commissioners and senior staff to the 
latest  developments  and  best  practices  within  the  region  in  quality  assurance,  university 
governance, and student assistance schemes. Two short attachments to appropriate regional 
agencies in higher education financing and quality assurance will also be included to provide 
CHED staff with experience in these areas. Details of the participants, including their current or 
proposed professional responsibilities, itineraries, and plans for all overseas activities must first 
be submitted to ADB for approval.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The total cost of 
the TA is estimated at $770,000, of which $500,000 will be financed by ADB on a grant basis 
covering the entire foreign exchange cost of $275,500, and $224,500 of the local currency cost. 
The Government’s contribution to the TA will be in cash and in kind, and will include the funding 
of training workshops and technical group meetings, provision of counterpart staff and working 
group  members,  local  travel  for  staff,  office  accommodation,  administrative  and  secretarial 
support, and use of printers and photocopiers. The Government’s contribution is estimated at 
$270,000 equivalent. The detailed cost estimates and proposed financing arrangements are in

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The TA will be implemented by CHED. An organizational development committee to be 
chaired by the Chairman of CHED will be formed to oversee TA implementation, guide the work 
of the consultants, and provide active input into ongoing work. The TA will be administered by a 
project management unit under the Office of Policy, Planning, Research and Information. A 
technical  working  group  composed  of  external  stakeholders  from  the  private  and  public 
education sectors will meet monthly to review TA progress and provide technical feedback. 
  
18.  The TA will be implemented over 10 months (15 January–15 November 2003). As the 
process  of  organizational  development  will  be  highly  inclusive  and  participatory,  frequent 
workshops, working group meetings, and field trips to the regional offices and some HEIs will be 
necessary.   
 
19.   The TA will require 15 person-months of local and 7 person-months of international 
consultancy input in organizational development, HRD, quality assurance, and higher education 
financing. ADB will engage a consultancy firm on the basis of a simplified technical proposal, in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  and  other  arrangements 
satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic consultants. The consultancy firm will be 
selected using ADB’s quality- and cost-based selection procedures. Equipment and furniture will 
be purchased in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. Outline terms of reference 
for the consultants are included in Appendix 3. The findings and recommendations of the 
consultants will be implemented and disseminated through the training activities to be led by 
each consultant. CHED will continue to advocate reform through national workshops with major 
stakeholders and the media, and in coordination with Congress. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
 
the Government of the Philippines for the Organizational Development of the Commission on 
Higher Education, and hereby reports such action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
1.  Five  consultants  will  be  required  in  organizational  development,  human  resource 
development (HRD), and reform of the higher education funding system. In total, 15 person-
months of local and 7 person-months of international consultancy input will be required to 
provide these services.   
A.  Organizational Development (Team Leader) 
2.  An  international  specialist  in  organizational  development  and  experienced  in  quality 
assurance in higher education (3 person-months), and a domestic organizational development 
specialist (6 person-months) will be recruited to (i) conduct a performance analysis to determine 
performance standards for the Commission on Higher Education (CHED), taking into account 
the planned changes in its functions, current performance, and performance gaps; (ii) conduct a 
diagnostic analysis to determine the main causes of the performance gaps, using the work 
completed under the project preparatory technical assistance as a basis; (iii) recommend and 
gain agreement on appropriate measures to address the problems and needs identified; (iv) 
recommend and gain agreement on the changes necessary to strengthen CHED’s role in 
resource allocation through the national budget and the Higher Education Development Fund; 
(v)  recommend  an  appropriate  organizational  structure  for  CHED,  including  functional  and 
position  charts  specifying  reporting  relationships;  (vi)  design  strategies  for  organizational 
change, including on-the-job training for senior staff in key reform areas in central and regional 
offices; (vii) design strategies and training programs to further decentralization, in coordination 
with the HRD specialist.  Two joint reports will be produced, the first covering the results of the 
performance  analysis  and  the  recommendations  agreed  on,  and  the  second  covering  the 
implementation  of  the  recommendations,  training  program  and  outputs,  and  an  overall 
evaluation  of  the  success  of  the  technical  assistance  (TA)  in  strengthening  CHED’s 
organizational capacity.    
B.  Human Resource Development 
3.  A domestic HRD specialist (4 person-months) will be recruited to (i) develop a costed, 5- 
year HRD plan on the basis of agreements on CHED’s new performance standards, main 
causes  of  current  underperformance,  requirements  of  CHED’s  future  strengthened  role  in 
resource allocation, and decentralization; (ii) design a new staffing structure, revise key job 
descriptions,  and  develop  criteria  for  performance  evaluation;  (iii)  recommend  and  gain 
agreement on the changes necessary to strengthen CHED’s HRD system; and (iv) on the basis 
of (iii), HRD staff in key areas, possibly including workforce planning, recruitment strategies, and 
skills upgrading. The consultant will produce a report containing the costed HRD plan, revised 
staffing  structure,  job  descriptions  and  performance  evaluation,  training  plan,  and  training 
outputs.     
C.  Higher Education Funding System 
4.  An  international  specialist  (3  person-months)  and  a  domestic  specialist  (5  person-
months) on formula-based financing for higher education financing will be recruited to design a 
new financing system for public higher education institutions (HEIs), for implementation under 
the proposed Higher Education Development Project. The new system will consist of three 
elements: (i) a normative funding formula, to be developed and implemented by CHED; (ii) a 
statement  of  national  higher  education  priorities,  to  be  developed  and  issued  regularly  by 
CHED, anchored in labor force needs as well as quality considerations; and (iii) the proportion 
of the costs incurred by public HEIs that the Government is willing to fund each year.

14  Appendix 3 
5.  Specifically, the consultant will (i) use the completed empirical studies on the costs of 
various  program  types  to  develop  cost-based  norms  for  different  programs  and  different 
program quality levels; (ii) develop a formula incorporating parameters such as quality, demand, 
discipline area, and national priority; (iii) help CHED develop and institutionalize a system to 
determine annual priorities in higher education based upon developments in the labor force and 
the economy, and to be used as a basis for the annual budgeting exercise; (iv) simulate the 
proposed normative financing system for selected public HEIs; (v) expand the coverage of the 
system  to  include  salaries  of  public  HEI  personnel;  (vi)  develop  a  plan  for  nationwide 
implementation; and (vii) ensure that the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) and 
the National Economic Development Authority are in agreement on all aspects of the proposed 
system; and (vii) train CHED and DBM staff to use the new system. Regular workshops will be 
held during the TA with the technical working group on normative financing and CHED staff to 
present the work in progress. The consultant will also produce a final report explaining the 
formula  developed,  results  of  the  simulations,  plan  for  nationwide  implementation,  training 
program provided, and future needs in normative financing.   
D.  Quality Assurance 
6.  An international specialist in quality assurance in higher education (1 person-month) will 
be recruited to (i) review CHED’s higher education monitoring system for quality assurance; (ii) 
recommend and gain agreement on CHED’s role in quality assurance; (iii) recommend and gain 
agreement on the changes necessary to strengthen the higher education monitoring system; 
and (iv) design a training program to prepare staff to implement the monitoring system, in 
collaboration with the HRD specialist (for incorporation into the 5-year HRD plan. The consultant 
will produce a final report describing the current monitoring and evaluation system, its strengths 
and  weakness,  agreements  reached  to  strengthen  the  system,  and  training  program.  The 
agreements reached on CHED’s overall role in quality assurance should also be presented.
